The Last of Us 2 represents how games sh: “The last of us part I” is only considered a powerful story because it’s bold ending. The story without it is simple\, linear and I it is quite standard. Of course it has good pace and amazing performances from all the cast\, but it’s filed with a very old Hollywood cliche: “traumatized grumpy middle age man gets soft after is forced to deal with a teenage rebel”. The game world is vast in possibilites and Part II takes advantage of them\, filling the not so linear story with a interesting background: the Seraphites reminds me of “The Handmaid’s Tale” world where religion is used as a pillar stone to manipulate and control people in a world of crisis. The WLF plot line demonstrates how a prominent society can be subdued to a twisted leader. But this informations of the world can only be enjoyed as long as you explore every corner of the game. And I was thrilled when the story took us to the Seraphite Island.Since I despised Joel’s decision to lie in the ending of the first game\, his fate in Part II is not revolting to my eyes\, and it reminded me of choice/consequence like Robb Stark and The Red Wedding. Where a choice based on a noble sentiment such as love\, can cause damage to others as a whole.Ellie felt way more interesting as a character in Part I than Joel; and her shift in personality in Part II is believable after all the trauma and lies she suffered through all her life.
